segment.source: Service a Mounted Windows Image
segment.target: Service a Mounted Windows Image

segment.source: Service a Mounted Windows Image
segment.target: Service a Mounted Windows Image

segment.source: Service a Mounted Windows Image
segment.target: Service a Mounted Windows Image

segment.source: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to mount a Windows image from a WIM or VHD file and modify it.
segment.target: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to mount a Windows image from a WIM or VHD file and modify it.

segment.source: In the first part of this walkthrough, you add a language pack, configuring international settings and enable Windows features.
segment.target: In the first part of this walkthrough, you add a language pack, configuring international settings and enable Windows features.

segment.source: In the second part, you remove a package, and then upgrade the Windows image to a higher edition of Windows®.
segment.target: In the second part, you remove a package, and then upgrade the Windows image to a higher edition of Windows®.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: To complete the walkthrough, you need the following:
segment.target: To complete the walkthrough, you need the following:

segment.source: A computer that has the Windows ADK tools installed on it.
segment.target: A computer that has the Windows ADK tools installed on it.

segment.source: A .wim, .vhd, or .vhdx file to update.
segment.target: A .wim, .vhd, or .vhdx file to update.

segment.source: Language packs, or other packages to add and remove from the image.
segment.target: Language packs, or other packages to add and remove from the image.

segment.source: Procedures
segment.target: Procedures

segment.source: Step 1: Mount an Image with Read/Write Permissions
segment.target: Step 1: Mount an Image with Read/Write Permissions

segment.source: In this step, you mount a Windows image to a specified directory, so that it is available for servicing.
segment.target: In this step, you mount a Windows image to a specified directory, so that it is available for servicing.

segment.source: Copy a .wim file, a .vhd, or a .vhdx that contains a Windows image, to the local drive.
segment.target: Copy a .wim file, a .vhd, or a .vhdx that contains a Windows image, to the local drive.

segment.source: For example, C:testimages.
segment.target: For example, C:testimages.

segment.source: Click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: Click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: Create a folder for your mounted image.
segment.target: Create a folder for your mounted image.

segment.source: For example, C:testoffline.
segment.target: For example, C:testoffline.

segment.source: Run the DISM /Get-ImageInfo command to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to update.
segment.target: Run the DISM /Get-ImageInfo command to retrieve the name or index number for the image that you want to update.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Mount the Windows image.
segment.target: Mount the Windows image.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Since WIM files can contain one or more images, you must specify an index or name value.
segment.target: Since WIM files can contain one or more images, you must specify an index or name value.

segment.source: To mount an image from a VHD, you must specify .
segment.target: To mount an image from a VHD, you must specify .

segment.source: Step 2: Add Packages to the Image
segment.target: Step 2: Add Packages to the Image

segment.source: In this step, you add packages to the mounted Windows image.
segment.target: In this step, you add packages to the mounted Windows image.

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, add packages to the mounted Windows image.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, add packages to the mounted Windows image.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: If you added a language pack, you can change all international language settings in the mounted offline image by typing the following command:
segment.target: If you added a language pack, you can change all international language settings in the mounted offline image by typing the following command:

segment.source: Optionally, you can configure different values for different settings, including UI language, system locale, user locale, input locale, and others.
segment.target: Optionally, you can configure different values for different settings, including UI language, system locale, user locale, input locale, and others.

segment.source: For more information about how to specify individual values for each of these settings, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about how to specify individual values for each of these settings, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: At the command prompt, commit the changes.
segment.target: At the command prompt, commit the changes.

segment.source: The image remains mounted until the /Unmount-Image option is used.
segment.target: The image remains mounted until the /Unmount-Image option is used.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Step 3: Remove a Package from the Mounted Image
segment.target: Step 3: Remove a Package from the Mounted Image

segment.source: In this step, you review the packages that have been installed in your image, and then remove a specific package from the image.
segment.target: In this step, you review the packages that have been installed in your image, and then remove a specific package from the image.

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, find the names of the packages that are in your image.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, find the names of the packages that are in your image.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: If the list of packages is extensive, you can output the information to a text file.
segment.target: If the list of packages is extensive, you can output the information to a text file.

segment.source: For example, you can add to the end of the command line.
segment.target: For example, you can add to the end of the command line.

segment.source: Review the list of packages that are available in your mounted image, and note the package identity of the package.
segment.target: Review the list of packages that are available in your mounted image, and note the package identity of the package.

segment.source: At a command prompt, specify the package identity of a package and remove it from the mounted image.
segment.target: At a command prompt, specify the package identity of a package and remove it from the mounted image.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Step 4: Upgrade to a Higher Edition of Windows
segment.target: Step 4: Upgrade to a Higher Edition of Windows

segment.source: All of the changes that you make are also applied to each potential target edition of Windows.
segment.target: All of the changes that you make are also applied to each potential target edition of Windows.

segment.source: Each target edition is staged in the image.
segment.target: Each target edition is staged in the image.

segment.source: The changes will not be lost when you upgrade to a higher edition of Windows.
segment.target: The changes will not be lost when you upgrade to a higher edition of Windows.

segment.source: For more information, see DISM Windows Edition-Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information, see DISM Windows Edition-Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, list the editions that are available for the upgrade.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, list the editions that are available for the upgrade.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Note the target edition ID.
segment.target: Note the target edition ID.

segment.source: At the command prompt, specify the edition that you want to upgrade to.
segment.target: At the command prompt, specify the edition that you want to upgrade to.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: End users can use Windows Anytime Upgrade to remove files related to lower editions of Windows that are not being used.
segment.target: End users can use Windows Anytime Upgrade to remove files related to lower editions of Windows that are not being used.

segment.source: Step 5: Reduce the Size of the Image
segment.target: Step 5: Reduce the Size of the Image

segment.source: In this step, you'll reduce the footprint of the image by cleaning up superseded components to reduce the size of the component store, and also by resetting the base of superseded components, which can further reduce the component store size.
segment.target: In this step, you'll reduce the footprint of the image by cleaning up superseded components to reduce the size of the component store, and also by resetting the base of superseded components, which can further reduce the component store size.

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, run the following command to reduce the size of the image file:
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, run the following command to reduce the size of the image file:

segment.source: Step 6: Commit the Changes and Unmount the Image
segment.target: Step 6: Commit the Changes and Unmount the Image

segment.source: In this step, you unmount the image and save the changes that you have made.
segment.target: In this step, you unmount the image and save the changes that you have made.

segment.source: At an elevated command prompt, unmount the image and commit the changes to the image file.
segment.target: At an elevated command prompt, unmount the image and commit the changes to the image file.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Next Step
segment.target: Next Step

segment.source: This walkthrough illustrates the basic offline servicing of a mounted Windows image.
segment.target: This walkthrough illustrates the basic offline servicing of a mounted Windows image.

segment.source: All the changes were made to a single image, and persisted when the image was upgraded.
segment.target: All the changes were made to a single image, and persisted when the image was upgraded.

segment.source: The updated image is ready to be deployed.
segment.target: The updated image is ready to be deployed.

segment.source: Because you copied the image file to the local hard disk drive, you can delete the original image file from the server.
segment.target: Because you copied the image file to the local hard disk drive, you can delete the original image file from the server.

segment.source: You can replace it with this new one, or keep a copy of the older version for reference.
segment.target: You can replace it with this new one, or keep a copy of the older version for reference.

segment.source: For more information about additional offline servicing operations that can be performed on an offline image, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about additional offline servicing operations that can be performed on an offline image, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.
